p: The interest in studying mint for human beings is majorly related to its phytosanitary effects. In fact, M. pulegium L. essential oil showed high efficiency against the food pest Sitophilus granaries, and could additionally be used as a bio-insecticide [ 32]. M. Ã— piperita L. aqueous extract improved radish seedlings ( Raphanus sativus L.) defensive responses against oxidative stress and had inhibitory effects on seed germination and seedling growth, thus representing a huge area of interest for natural herbicide formulation [ 33]. Mint phenols have also shown strong antioxidant, acetylcholinesterase (AChE), butyrylcholinesterase (BChE) and histone deacetylase inhibitory effects [ 34, 35, 36, 37, 38].
